bestBHT.bht: After witnessing the miracle of Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead, some people began to withdraw from the company of the chief priests and Pharisees. The narrative suggests that these people visited Bethany after sunset on the Sabbath and were influenced by what they heard from the multitude. By witnessing the power of Jesus firsthand, they found their interest in the opposition decreasing and their belief in Jesus as the Messiah increasing.

Henry Alford: The word contains in it the sense of mere falling away, viz. from under the hand and power of the chief priests.
The order of the narrative seems to require that these people should have visited Bethany late on the Sabbath, after sunset, and the anointing.
when they heard] From the multitude who had returned from Bethany, ver. 9.
Marvin Vincent: Went away [υπηγον] . Withdrew from their company.
Archibald T. Robertson: Because of him, began to withdraw.
There was danger of a mass movement of the people to Jesus.
John Gill: Because that by reason of him,.... Of the miracle which was wrought upon him, in raising him from the dead, of which he was a living and an abiding witness...

many of the Jews went away; not from Jerusalem only, but from the chief priests and Pharisees, and the rest of the Jews, that combined against Christ; they withdrew themselves from their party, and deserted them...
and believed on Jesus; as the Messiah; so that they found their interest was decreasing and weakening every day, and that those on the side of Christ were increasing...

bhtAttempts.bht: After witnessing the miracle of Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead, some people began to withdraw from the company of the chief priests and Pharisees. This mass movement towards Jesus caused a weakening of the opposition's interest and an increasing number of believers in Jesus as the Messiah. The narrative suggests that these people visited Bethany after sunset on the Sabbath and were influenced by what they heard from the multitude who had returned from Bethany. By witnessing the power of Jesus firsthand, they were compelled to abandon their former allegiance and place their faith in Jesus as the true Messiah.

After witnessing the miracle of Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead, some people began to withdraw from their former allegiance and place their faith in Jesus as the true Messiah. The narrative suggests that these people visited Bethany after sunset on the Sabbath and were influenced by what they heard from the multitude who had returned from Bethany. The narrative of John 12:11 reveals that after witnessing Jesus raising Lazarus from the dead, some people began to withdraw from their former allegiance to the chief priests and Pharisees. These people visited Bethany after sunset on the Sabbath and were influenced by what they heard from the multitude. By witnessing the power of Jesus firsthand, their interest in the opposition decreased and their belief in Jesus as the true Messiah increased.
